PLAY.TITLE: The Life of Timon of Athens

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pœt, Painter, Ieweller, Merchant, and Mercer, at ſeuerall doores

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad y'are well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue not ſeene you long, how goes the World?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: It weares ſir, as it growes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: I that’s well knowne:
But what particular Rarity? What ſtrange,
Which manifold record not matches: ſee
Magicke of Bounty, all these ſpirits thy power
Hath coniur’d to attend.
I know the Merchant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: I know them both: th’ others a Ieweller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: O ‘tis a worthy Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that’s mo’t fixt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t incomparable man, breath’d as it were,
To an vntyreable and continuate goodneſſe:
He paſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a Iewell heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: O pray let's ſee't. For the Lord Timon, ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iewel.
SPEECH.LINE: If he will touch the estimate. But for that—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: When we for recompence haue prais’d the vild,
It ſtaines the glory in that happy Verse,
Which aptly ſings the good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a good forme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iewel.
SPEECH.LINE: And rich: heere is a Water looke ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: You are rapt ſir, in ſome worke, ſome Dedica-tion to the great Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: A thing ſlipt idlely from me.
Our Pœsie is as a Gowne, which vses
From whence ‘tis nourisht: the fire i'th’ Flint
Shewes not, till it be ſtrooke: our gentle flame
Prouokes it ſelfe, and like the currant flyes
Each bound it chases. What haue you there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: A Picture ſir: when comes your Booke forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon the heeles of my presentment ſir.
Let's ſee your peece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a good Peece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: So ‘tis, this comes off well, and excellent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: Indifferent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Admirable: How this grace
Speakes his owne ſtanding: what a mentall power
This eye ſhootes forth? How bigge imagination
Moues in this Lip, to th’ dumbneſſe of the gesture,
One might interpret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a pretty mocking of the life:
Heere is a touch: Is't good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſay of it,
It Tutors Nature, Artificiall ſtrife
Liues in these toutches, liuelier then life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: How this Lord is followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: The Senators of Athens, happy men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke moe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Po.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſee this confluence, this great flood of visitors,
I haue in this rough worke, ſhap’d out a man
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hugge
With amplest entertainment: My free drift
Halts not particularly, but moues it ſelfe
In a wide Sea of wax, no leuell’d malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold,
But flies an Eagle flight, bold, and forth on,
Leauing no Tract behinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhall I vnderstand you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: I will vnboult to you.
You ſee how all Conditions, how all Mindes,
As well of glib and ſlipp'ry Creatures, as
Of Graue and austere qualitie, tender downe
Their ſeruices to Lord Timon: his large Fortune,
Vpon his good and gracious Nature hanging,
Subdues and properties to his loue and tendance
All ſorts of hearts; yea, from the glaſſe-fac’d Flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loues better
Then to abhorre himselfe; euen hee drops downe
The knee before him, and returnes in peace
Mo’t rich in Timons nod.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw them ſpeake together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I haue vpon a high and pleasant hill
Feign’d Fortune to be thron’d.
The Base o'th’ Mount
Is rank’d with all deserts, all kinde of Natures
That labour on the bosome of this Sphere,
To propagate their ſtates; among'st them all,
Whose eyes are on this Soueraigne Lady fixt,
One do I personate of Lord Timons frame,
Whom Fortune with her Iuory hand wafts to her,
Whose present grace, to present ſlaues and ſeruants
Translates his Riuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis conceyu’d, to ſcope
This Throne, this Fortune, and this Hill me thinkes
With one man becken’d from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the ſleepy Mount
To climbe his happineſſe, would be well exprest
In our Condition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Sir, but heare me on:
All those which were his Fellowes but of late,
Some better then his valew; on the moment
Follow his ſtrides, his Lobbies fill with tendance,
Raine Sacrificiall whisperings in his eare,
Make Sacred euen his ſtyrrop, and through him
Drinke the free Ayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry, what of these?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: When Fortune in her ſhift and change of mood
Spurnes downe her late beloued; all his Dependants
Which labour’d after him to the Mountaines top,
Euen on their knees and hand, let him ſit downe,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis common: A thousand morall Paintings I can ſhew, That ſhall demonstrate these quicke blowes of Fortunes, More pregnantly then words. Yet you do well, To ſhew Lord Timon, that meane eyes haue ſeene The foot aboue the head. Trumpets ſound.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Lord Timon, addreſſing himselfe curteously to euery Sutor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Imprison’d is he, ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord, fiue Talents is his debt,
His meanes mo’t ſhort, his Creditors mo’t ſtraite:
Your Honourable Letter he desires
To those haue ſhut him vp, which failing,
Periods his comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Ventidius, well:
I am not of that Feather, to ſhake off
My Friend when he must neede me. I do know him
A Gentleman, that well deserues a helpe,
Which he ſhall haue. Ile pay the debt, and free him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lordship euer bindes him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Commend me to him, I will ſend his ransome,
And being enfranchized bid him come to me;
‘Tis not enough to helpe the Feeble vp,
But to ſupport him after. Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes
SPEECH.LINE: All happineſſe to your Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Timon, heare me ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Freely good Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast a Seruant nam’d Lucilius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſo: What of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Noble Timon, call the man before thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Attends he heere, or no? Lucillius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere at your Lordships ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: This Fellow heere, L[ord]. Timon, this thy Creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first haue beene inclin’d to thrift,
And my estate deserues an Heyre more rais’d,
Then one which holds a Trencher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: what further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: One onely Daughter haue I, no Kin else,
On whom I may conferre what I haue got:
The Maid is faire, a'th’ youngest for a Bride,
And I haue bred her at my deerest cost
In Qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her loue: I prythee (Noble Lord)
Ioyne with me to forbid him her resort,
My ſelfe haue ſpoke in vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: The man is honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore he will be Timon,
His honesty rewards him in it ſelfe,
It must not beare my Daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Does ſhe loue him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: She is yong and apt:
Our owne precedent paſſions do instruct vs
What leuities in youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue you the Maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord, and ſhe accepts of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: If in her Marriage my consent be miſſing,
I call the Gods to witneſſe, I will choose
Mine heyre from forth the Beggers of the world,
And dispoſſeſſe her all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhall ſhe be endowed,
If ſhe be mated with an equall Husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Three Talents on the present; in future, all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: This Gentleman of mine
Hath ſeru’d me long:
To build his Fortune, I will ſtraine a little,
For ‘tis a Bond in men. Giue him thy Daughter,
What you bestow, in him Ile counterpoize,
And make him weigh with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Noble Lord,
Pawne me to this your Honour, ſhe is his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: My hand to thee,
Mine Honour on my promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Humbly I thanke your Lordship, neuer may
That ſtate or Fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Vouchsafe my Labour,
And long liue your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you, you ſhall heare from me anon:
Go not away. What haue you there, my Friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: A peece of Painting, which I do beseech
Your Lordship to accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Painting is welcome.
The Painting is almost the Naturall man:
For ſince Dishonor Traffickes with mans Nature,
He is but out-side: These Pensil’d Figures are
Euen ſuch as they giue out. I like your worke,
And you ſhall finde I like it; Waite attendance
Till you heare further from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods preserue ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Well fare you Gentleman: giue me your hand.
We must needs dine together: ſir your Iewell
Hath ſuffered vnder praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iewel.
SPEECH.LINE: What my Lord, dispraise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: A meere ſaciety of Commendations,
If I ſhould pay you for't as ‘tis extold,
It would vnclew me quite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iewel.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, ‘tis rated
As those which ſell would giue: but you well know,
Things of like valew differing in the Owners,
Are prized by their Masters. Beleeu't deere Lord,
You mend the Iewell by the wearing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim
SPEECH.LINE: Well mock’d. Enter Apermantus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, he ſpeakes y common toong
Which all men ſpeake with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke who comes heere, will you be chid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iewel.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l beare with your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee'l ſpare none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow to thee,
Gentle Apermantus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Till I be gentle, ſtay thou for thy good morrow.
When thou art Timons dogge, and these Knaues honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Why dost thou call them Knaues, thou know'st them not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Are they not Athenians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I repent not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: You know me, Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know'st I do, I call’d thee by thy name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art proud Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Of nothing ſo much, as that I am not like Timon

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether art going?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: To knocke out an honeſt Athenians braines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a deed thou't dye for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Right, if doing nothing be death by th’ Law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: How lik'st thou this picture Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: The best, for the innocence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Wrought he not well that painted it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: He wrought better that made the Painter, and yet he's but a filthy peece of worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pain.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are a Dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Mothers of my generation: what’s ſhe, if I be a Dogge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt dine with me Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: No: I eate not Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou ſhould'st, thoud'st anger Ladies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: O they eate Lords;
So they come by great bellies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a lasciuious apprehension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: So, thou apprehend'st it,
Take it for thy labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: How dost thou like this Iewell, Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo well as plain-dealing, which wil not cast a man a Doit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What dost thou thinke ‘tis worth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Not worth my thinking.
How now Pœt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Philosopher?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Art not one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I lye not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Art not a Pœt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thou lyest: Looke in thy last worke, where thou hast feign’d him a worthy Fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: That's not feign’d, he is ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy labour. He that loues to be flattered, is worthy o'th flat-terer. Heauens, that I were a Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst do then Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: E'ne as Apemantus does now, hate a Lord with my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What thy ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: That I had no angry wit to be a Lord.
Art not thou a Merchant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: I Apemantus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Traffick confound thee, if the Gods will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: If Trafficke do it, the Gods do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Traffickes thy God, & thy God confound thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What Trumpets that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Alcibiades, and ſome twenty Horse
All of Companionship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray entertaine them, giue them guide to vs.
You must needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I haue thankt you: when dinners done
Shew me this peece, I am ioyfull of your ſights.
Mo’t welcome Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: So, ſo; their Aches contract, and ſterue your ſupple ioynts: that there ſhould bee ſmall loue amongest these ſweet Knaues, and all this Curtesie. The ſtraine of mans bred out into Baboon and Monkey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you haue ſau’d my longing, and I feed
Mo’t hungerly on your ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Right welcome Sir:
Ere we depart, wee'l ſhare a bounteous time
In different pleasures.
Pray you let vs in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord
SPEECH.LINE: What time a day is't Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Time to be honeſt.
That time ſerues ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: The mo’t accursed thou that ſtill omitst it.
Thou art going to Lord Timons Feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: I, to ſee meate fill Knaues, and Wine heat fooles.
Farthee well, farthee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Foole to bid me farewell twice.
Why Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Should'st haue kept one to thy ſelfe, for I meane to giue thee none.
Hang thy ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: No I will do nothing at thy bidding:
Make thy requests to thy Friend.
Away vnpeaceable Dogge,
Or Ile ſpurne thee hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: I will flye like a dogge, the heeles a'th’ Aſſe.
Hee's opposite to humanity.
Come ſhall we in,
And taste Lord Timons bountie: he out-goes
The verie heart of kindneſſe.
He powres it out: Plutus the God of Gold
Is but his Steward: no meede but he repayes
Seuen-fold aboue it ſelfe: No guift to him,
But breeds the giuer a returne: exceeding
All vse of quittance.
The Noblest minde he carries,
That euer gouern’d man.
Long may he liue in Fortunes. Shall we in? Ile keepe you Company.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Hoboyes Playing lowd Musicke. A great Banquet ſeru’d in: and then, Enter Lord Timon, the States, the Athenian Lords, Ventigius which Timon re-deem’d from prison. Then comes dropping after all Ape-mantus discontentedly like himselfe

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ventig.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t honoured Timon,
It hath pleas’d the Gods to remember my Fathers age,
And call him to long peace:
He is gone happy, and has left me rich:
Then, as in gratefull Vertue I am bound
To your free heart, I do returne those Talents
Doubled with thankes and ſeruice, from whose helpe
I deriu’d libertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: O by no meanes,
Honest Ventigius: You mistake my loue,
I gaue it freely euer, and ther's none
Can truely ſay he giues, if he receiues:
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them: faults that are rich are faire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vint.
SPEECH.LINE: A Noble ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay my Lords, Ceremony was but deuis’d at first
To ſet a gloſſe on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodneſſe, ſorry ere ‘tis ſhowne:
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray ſit, more welcome are ye to my Fortunes,
Then my Fortunes to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, we alwaies haue confest it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Ho ho, confest it? Handg’d it? Haue you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Timo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Apermantus, you are welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: No: You ſhall not make me welcome:
I come to haue thee thrust me out of doores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, th’art a churle, ye'haue got a humour there
Does not become a man, ‘tis much too blame:
They ſay my Lords, Ira furor breuis est,
But yond man is verie angrie.
Go, let him haue a Table by himselfe:
For he does neither affect companie,
Nor is he fit for't indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſtay at thine apperill Timon,
I come to obserue, I giue thee warning on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I take no heede of thee: Th'art an Athenian, therefore welcome: I my ſelfe would haue no power, prythee let my meate make thee ſilent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſcorne thy meate, 'twould choake me: for I ſhould nere flatter thee. Oh you Gods! What a number of men eats Timon, and he ſees 'em not? It greeues me to ſee ſo many dip there meate in one mans blood, and all the madneſſe is, he cheeres them vp too. I wonder men dare trust themselues with men. Me thinks they ſhould enuite them without kniues, Good for there meate, and ſafer for their liues. There's much example for't, the fellow that ſits next him, now parts bread with him, pledges the breath of him in a diuided draught: is the readiest man to kill him. 'Tas beene proued, if I were a huge man I ſhould feare to drinke at meales, least they ſhould ſpie my wind-pipes dangerous noates, great men ſhould drinke with harneſſe on their throates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord in heart: and let the health go round.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it flow this way my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Flow this way? A braue fellow. He keepes his tides well, those healths will make thee and thy ſtate looke ill, Timon. Heere's that which is too weake to be a ſinner, Honest water, which nere left man i'th’ mire: This and my food are equals, there's no ods, Feasts are to proud to giue thanks to the Gods. Apermantus Grace. Immortall Gods, I craue no pelfe, I pray for no man but my ſelfe, Graunt I may neuer proue ſo fond, To trust man on his Oath or Bond. Or a Harlot for her weeping, Or a Dogge that ſeemes asleeping, Or a keeper with my freedome, Or my friends if I ſhould need 'em. Amen. So fall too't: Richmen ſin, and I eat root. Much good dich thy good heart, Apermantus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Captaine,
Alcibiades, your hearts in the field now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alci.
SPEECH.LINE: My heart is euer at your ſeruice, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You had rather be at a breakefast of Enemies, then a dinner of Friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: So they were bleeding new my Lord, there's no meat like 'em, I could wish my best friend at ſuch a Feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Would all those Flatterers were thine Enemies then, that then thou might'st kill 'em: & bid me to 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Might we but haue that happineſſe my Lord, that you would once vse our hearts, whereby we might expreſſe ſome part of our zeales, we ſhould thinke our ſelues for euer perfect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Timon.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh no doubt my good Friends, but the Gods themselues haue prouided that I ſhall haue much helpe from you: how had you beene my Friends else. Why haue you that charitable title from thousands? Did not you chiefely belong to my heart? I haue told more of you to my ſelfe, then you can with modestie ſpeake in your owne behalfe. And thus farre I confirme you. Oh you Gods (thinke I,) what need we haue any Friends; if we ſhould nere haue need of 'em? They were the mo’t needleſſe Creatures liuing; ſhould we nere haue vse for 'em? And would mo’t resemble ſweete Instruments hung vp in Cases, that keepes there ſounds to them-selues. Why I haue often wisht my ſelfe poorer, that I might come neerer to you: we are borne to do bene-fits. And what better or properer can we call our owne, then the riches of our Friends? Oh what a pretious com-fort ‘tis, to haue ſo many like Brothers commanding one anothers Fortunes. Oh ioyes, e'ne made away er't can be borne: mine eies cannot hold out water me thinks to forget their Faults. I drinke to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou weep'st to make them drinke, Timon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Ioy had the like conception in our eies,
And at that instant, like a babe ſprung vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Ho, ho: I laugh to thinke that babe a bastard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: I promise you my Lord you mou’d me much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Much.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sound Tucket. Enter the Maskers of Amazons, with Lutes in their hands, dauncing and playing

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes that Trumpe? How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you my Lord, there are certaine Ladies
Mo’t desirous of admittance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladies? what are their wils?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: There comes with them a fore-runner my Lord, which beares that office, to ſignifie their pleasures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray let them be admitted.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cupid with the Maske of Ladies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cup.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to thee worthy Timon and to all that of his Bounties taste: the fiue best Sences acknowledge thee their Patron, and come freely to gratulate thy plentious bosome. There tast, touch all, pleas’d from thy Table rise: They onely now come but to Feast thine eies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Timo.
SPEECH.LINE: They'r welcome all, let 'em haue kind admit-tance.
Musicke make their welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſee my Lord, how ample y'are belou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoyday, What a ſweepe of vanitie comes this way. They daunce? They are madwomen, Like Madneſſe is the glory of this life, As this pompe ſhewes to a little oyle and roote. We make our ſelues Fooles, to disport our ſelues, And ſpend our Flatteries, to drinke those men, Vpon whose Age we voyde it vp agen With poysonous Spight and Enuy. Who liues, that’s not depraued, or depraues; Who dyes, that beares not one ſpurne to their graues Of their Friends guift: I ſhould feare, those that dance before me now, Would one day ſtampe vpon me: 'Tas bene done, Men ſhut their doores against a ſetting Sunne.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The Lords rise from Table, with much adoring of Timon, and to ſhew their loues, each ſingle out an Amazon, and all Dance, men with women, a loftie ſtraine or two to the Hoboyes, and cease

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue done our pleasures
Much grace (faire Ladies)
Set a faire fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not halfe ſo beautifull, and kinde:
You haue added worth vntoo't, and luster,
And entertain’d me with mine owne deuice.
I am to thanke you for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord you take vs euen at the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith for the worst is filthy, and would not hold taking, I doubt me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you,
Please you to dispose your ſelues.
All La
Mo’t thankfully, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Flauius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fla.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: The little Casket bring me hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fla.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, my Lord. More Iewels yet?
There is no croſſing him in's humor,
Else I ſhould tell him well, yfaith I ſhould;
When all's ſpent, hee'ld be crost then, and he could:
‘Tis pitty Bounty had not eyes behinde,
That man might ne're be wretched for his minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Where be our men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere my Lord, in readineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Horses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Friends:
I haue one word to ſay to you: Looke you, my good L[ord].
I must intreat you honour me ſo much,
As to aduance this Iewell, accept it, and weare it,
Kinde my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſo farre already in your guifts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: So are we all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, there are certaine Nobles of the Senate newly alighted, and come to visit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: They are fairely welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fla.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech your Honor, vouchsafe me a word, it does concerne you neere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Neere? why then another time Ile heare thee.
I prythee let's be prouided to ſhew them entertainment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fla.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſcarse know how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: May it please your Honor, Lord Lucius
(Out of his free loue) hath presented to you
Foure Milke-white Horses, trapt in Siluer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall accept them fairely: let the Presents
Be worthily entertain’d.
How now? What newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you my Lord, that honourable Gentle-man Lord Lucullus, entreats your companie to morrow, to hunt with him, and ha's ſent your Honour two brace of Grey-hounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile hunt with him,
And let them be receiu’d, not without faire Reward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fla.
SPEECH.LINE: What will this come to? He commands vs to prouide, and giue great guifts, and all out of an empty Coffer: Nor will he know his Purse, or yeeld me this, To ſhew him what a Begger his heart is, Being of no power to make his wishes good. His promises flye ſo beyond his ſtate, That what he ſpeaks is all in debt, he ows for eu'ry word: He is ſo kinde, that he now payes interest for't; His Land's put to their Bookes. Well, would I were Gently put out of Office, before I were forc’d out: Happier is he that has no friend to feede, Then ſuch that do e'ne Enemies exceede. I bleed inwardly for my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You do your ſelues much wrong,
You bate too much of your owne merits.
Heere my Lord, a trifle of our Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: With more then common thankes
I will receyue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: O he's the very ſoule of Bounty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: And now I remember my Lord, you gaue good words the other day of a Bay Courser I rod on. Tis yours because you lik’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.L.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I beseech you pardon mee, my Lord, in that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You may take my word my Lord: I know no man can iustly praise, but what he does affect. I weighe my Friends affection with mine owne: Ile tell you true, Ile call to you. All Lor. O none ſo welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I take all, and your ſeuerall visitations
So kinde to heart, ‘tis not enough to giue:
Me thinkes, I could deale Kingdomes to my Friends,
And nere be wearie. Alcibiades,
Thou art a Soldiour, therefore ſildome rich,
It comes in Charitie to thee: for all thy liuing
Is mong'st the dead: and all the Lands thou hast
Lye in a pitcht field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, defil’d Land, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: We are ſo vertuously bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: So infinitely endeer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: All to you. Lights, more Lights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: The best of Happines, Honor, and Fortunes
Keepe with you Lord Timon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim
SPEECH.LINE: Ready for his Friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: What a coiles heere, ſeruing of beckes, and iut-ting out of bummes. I doubt whether their Legges be worth the ſummes that are giuen for 'em. Friendships full of dregges, Me thinkes false hearts, ſhould neuer haue ſound legges. Thus honeſt Fooles lay out their wealth on Curtsies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Apermantus (if thou wert not ſullen)
I would be good to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile nothing; for if I ſhould be brib’d too, there would be none left to raile vpon thee, and then thou wouldst ſinne the faster. Thou giu'st ſo long Timon (I feare me) thou wilt giue away thy ſelfe in paper ſhortly. What needs these Feasts, pompes, and Vaine-glories?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, and you begin to raile on Societie once, I am ſworne not to giue regard to you. Farewell, & come with better Musicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aper.
SPEECH.LINE: So: Thou wilt not heare mee now, thou ſhalt not then. Ile locke thy heauen from thee: Oh that mens eares ſhould be To Counsell deafe, but not to Flatterie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: And late fiue thousand: to Varro and to Isidore
He owes nine thousand, besides my former ſumme,
Which makes it fiue and twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waste? It cannot hold, it will not.
If I want Gold, ſteale but a beggers Dogge,
And giue it Timon, why the Dogge coines Gold.
If I would ſell my Horse, and buy twenty moe
Better then he; why giue my Horse to Timon.
Aske nothing, giue it him, it Foles me ſtraight
And able Horses: No Porter at his gate,
But rather one that ſmiles, and ſtill inuites
All that paſſe by. It cannot hold, no reason
Can ſound his ſtate in ſafety. Caphis hoa,
Caphis I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ſir, what is your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Get on your cloake, & hast you to Lord Timon,
Importune him for my Moneyes, be not ceast
With ſlight deniall; nor then ſilenc’d, when
Commend me to your Master, and the Cap
Playes in the right hand, thus: but tell him,
My Vses cry to me; I must ſerue my turne
Out of mine owne, his dayes and times are past,
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Haue ſmit my credit. I loue, and honour him,
But must not breake my backe, to heale his finger.
Immediate are my needs, and my releefe
Must not be tost and turn’d to me in words,
But finde ſupply immediate. Get you gone,
Put on a mo’t importunate aspect,
A visage of demand: for I do feare
When euery Feather ſtickes in his owne wing,
Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
Which flashes now a Phœnix, get you gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: I go ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: I go ſir?
Take the Bonds along with you,
And haue the dates in. Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: I will Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen
SPEECH.LINE: Go.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Steward, with many billes in his hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: No care, no ſtop, ſo ſenseleſſe of expence,
That he will neither know how to maintaine it,
Nor cease his flow of Riot. Takes no accompt
How things go from him, nor resume no care
Of what is to continue: neuer minde,
Was to be ſo vnwise, to be ſo kinde.
What ſhall be done, he will not heare, till feele:
I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.
Fye, fie, fie, fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Good euen Varro: what, you come for money?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't not your busineſſe too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: It is, and yours too, Isidore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isid.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Would we were all discharg’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare it,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes the Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſoone as dinners done, wee'l forth againe
My Alcibiades. With me, what is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, heere is a note of certaine dues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Dues? whence are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Athens heere, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Go to my Steward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Please it your Lordship, he hath put me off
To the ſucceſſion of new dayes this moneth:
My Master is awak’d by great Occasion,
To call vpon his owne, and humbly prayes you,
That with your other Noble parts, you'l ſuite,
In giuing him his right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine honeſt Friend,
I prythee but repaire to me next morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Containe thy ſelfe, good Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: One Varrœs ſeruant, my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isid.
SPEECH.LINE: From Isidore, he humbly prayes your ſpeedy pay-ment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: If you did know my Lord, my Masters wants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas due on forfeyture my Lord, ſixe weekes, and past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isi.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Steward puts me off my Lord, and I
Am ſent expreſſely to your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me breath:
I do beseech you good my Lords keepe on,
Ile waite vpon you instantly. Come hither: pray you
How goes the world, that I am thus encountred
With clamorous demands of debt, broken Bonds,
And the detention of long ſince due debts
Against my Honor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you Gentlemen,
The time is vnagreeable to this busineſſe:
Your importunacie cease, till after dinner,
That I may make his Lordship vnderstand
Wherefore you are not paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo my Friends, ſee them well entertain’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew
SPEECH.LINE: Pray draw neere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caph.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, ſtay, here comes the Foole with Apeman-tus, let's ha ſome ſport with 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him, hee'l abuse vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isid.
SPEECH.LINE: A plague vpon him dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: How dost Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost Dialogue with thy ſhadow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpeake not to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: No ‘tis to thy ſelfe. Come away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isi.
SPEECH.LINE: There's the Foole hangs on your backe already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: No thou ſtand'st ſingle, th’art not on him yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's the Foole now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: He last ask’d the question. Poore Rogues, and
Vsurers men, Bauds betweene Gold and want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: What are we Apemantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: That you ask me what you are, & do not know your ſelues. Speake to 'em Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: How do you Gentlemen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Gramercies good Foole:
How does your Mistris?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: She's e'ne ſetting on water to ſcal’d ſuch Chic-kens as you are. Would we could ſee you at Corinth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Good, Gramercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke you, heere comes my Masters Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Captaine? what do you in this wise Company. How dost thou Apermantus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I had a Rod in my mouth, that I might anſwer thee profitably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee Apemantus reade me the ſuperscripti-on of these Letters, I know not which is which.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Canst not read?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: There will litle Learning dye then that day thou art hang’d. This is to Lord Timon, this to Alcibiades. Go thou was't borne a Bastard, and thou't dye a Bawd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou was't whelpt a Dogge, and thou ſhalt famish a Dogges death. Answer not, I am gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: E'ne ſo thou out-runst Grace,
Foole I will go with you to Lord Timons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you leaue me there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: If Timon ſtay at home.
You three ſerue three Vsurers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: I would they ſeru’d vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: So would I:
As good a tricke as euer Hangman ſeru’d Theefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you three Vsurers men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: I Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke no Vsurer, but ha's a Foole to his Ser-uant. My Mistris is one, and I am her Foole: when men come to borrow of your Masters, they approach ſadly, and go away merry: but they enter my Masters house merrily, and go away ſadly. The reason of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: I could render one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ap.
SPEECH.LINE: Do it then, that we may account thee a Whore-master, and a Knaue, which notwithstanding thou ſhalt be no leſſe esteemed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: What is a Whoremaster Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: A Foole in good cloathes, and ſomething like thee. ‘Tis a ſpirit, ſometime t’ appeares like a Lord, ſom-time like a Lawyer, ſometime like a Philosopher, with two ſtones moe then's artificiall one. Hee is verie often like a Knight; and generally, in all ſhapes that man goes vp and downe in, from fourescore to thirteen, this ſpirit walkes in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art not altogether a Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor thou altogether a Wise man,
As much foolerie as I haue, ſo much wit thou lack'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: That anſwer might haue become Apemantus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Aside, aside, heere comes Lord Timon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ape.
SPEECH.LINE: Come with me (Foole) come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not alwayes follow Louer, elder Brother, and Woman, ſometime the Philosopher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you walke neere,
Ile ſpeake with you anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You make me meruell wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laide my ſtate before me,
That I might ſo haue rated my expence
As I had leaue of meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: You would not heare me:
At many leysures I propose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too:
Perchance ſome ſingle vantages you tooke,
When my indisposition put you backe,
And that vnaptneſſe made your minister
Thus to excuse your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord,
At many times I brought in my accompts,
Laid them before you, you would throw them off,
And ſay you ſound them in mine honestie,
When for ſome trifling present you haue bid me
Returne ſo much, I haue ſhooke my head, and wept:
Yea 'gainst th’ Authoritie of manners, pray’d you
To hold your hand more close: I did indure
Not ſildome, nor no ſlight checkes, when I haue
Prompted you in the ebbe of your estate,
And your great flow of debts; my lou’d Lord,
Though you heare now (too late) yet nowes a time,
The greatest of your hauing, lackes a halfe,
To pay your present debts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Let all my Land be ſold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis all engag’d, ſome forfeyted and gone,
And what remaines will hardly ſtop the mouth
Of present dues; the future comes apace:
What ſhall defend the interim, and at length
How goes our reck'ning?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: To Lacedemon did my Land extend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord, the world is but a word,
Were it all yours, to giue it in a breath,
How quickely were it gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You tell me true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſuspect my Husbandry or Falshood,
Call me before th’ exactest Auditors,
And ſet me on the proofe. So the Gods bleſſe me,
When all our Offices haue beene opprest
With riotous Feeders, when our Vaults haue wept
With drunken ſpilth of Wine; when euery roome
Hath blaz’d with Lights, and braid with Minstrelsie,
I haue retyr’d me to a wastefull cocke,
And ſet mine eyes at flow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens, haue I ſaid, the bounty of this Lord:
How many prodigall bits haue Slaues and Pezants
This night englutted: who is not Timons,
What heart, head, ſword, force, meanes, but is L[ord]. Timons:
Great Timon, Noble, Worthy, Royall Timon:
Ah, when the meanes are gone, that buy this praise,
The breath is gone, whereof this praise is made:
Feast won, fast lost; one cloud of Winter ſhowres,
These flyes are coucht.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſermon me no further.
No villanous bounty yet hath past my heart;
Vnwisely, not ignobly haue I giuen.
Why dost thou weepe, canst thou the conscience lacke,
To thinke I ſhall lacke friends: ſecure thy heart,
If I would broach the veſſels of my loue,
And try the argument of hearts, by borrowing,
Men, and mens fortunes could I frankely vse
As I can bid thee ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſurance bleſſe your thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: And in ſome ſort these wants of mine are crown’d,
That I account them bleſſings. For by these
Shall I trie Friends. You ſhall perceiue
How you mistake my Fortunes:
I am wealthie in my Friends.
Within there, Flauius, Seruilius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I will dispatch you ſeuerally. You to Lord Lucius, to Lord Lucullus you, I hunted with his Honor to day; you to Sempronius; commend me to their loues; and I am proud ſay, that my occasions haue found time to vse 'em toward a ſupply of mony: let the request be fifty Talents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: As you haue ſaid, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Go you ſir to the Senators;
Of whom, euen to the States best health; I haue
Deseru’d this Hearing: bid 'em ſend o'th’ instant
A thousand Talents to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene bold
(For that I knew it the mo’t generall way)
To them, to vse your Signet, and your Name,
But they do ſhake their heads, and I am heere
No richer in returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't true? Can't be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: They anſwer in a ioynt and corporate voice,
That now they are at fall, want Treasure cannot
Do what they would, are ſorrie: you are Honourable,
But yet they could haue wisht, they know not,
Something hath beene amiſſe; a Noble Nature
May catch a wrench; would all were well; tis pitty,
And ſo intending other ſerious matters,
After distastefull lookes; and these hard Fractions
With certaine halfe-caps, and cold mouing nods,
They froze me into Silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: You Gods reward them:
Prythee man looke cheerely. These old Fellowes
Haue their ingratitude in them Hereditary:
Their blood is cak’d, ‘tis cold, it ſildome flowes,
‘Tis lacke of kindely warmth, they are not kinde;
And Nature, as it growes againe toward earth,
Is fashion’d for the iourney, dull and heauy.
Go to Ventiddius (prythee be not ſad,
Thou art true, and honeſt; Ingeniously I ſpeake,
No blame belongs to thee:) Ventiddius lately
Buried his Father, by whose death hee's ſtepp’d
Into a great estate: When he was poore,
Imprison’d, and in ſcarsitie of Friends,
I cleer’d him with fiue Talents: Greet him from me,
Bid him ſuppose, ſome good neceſſity
Touches his Friend, which craues to be remembred
With those fiue Talents; that had, giue't these Fellowes
To whom ‘tis instant due. Neu'r ſpeake, or thinke,
That Timons fortunes 'mong his Friends can ſinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I could not thinke it:
That thought is Bounties Fœ;
Being free it ſelfe, it thinkes all others ſo.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flaminius waiting to ſpeake with a Lord from his Master, enters a ſeruant to him

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue told my Lord of you, he is comming down to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: One of Lord Timons men? A Guift I warrant. Why this hits right: I dreampt of a Siluer Bason & Ewre to night. Flaminius, honeſt Flaminius, you are verie re-spectiuely welcome ſir. Fill me ſome Wine. And how does that Honourable, Compleate, Free-hearted Gentle-man of Athens, thy very bountifull good Lord and May-ster? _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: His health is well ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I am right glad that his health is well ſir: and what hast thou there vnder thy Cloake, pretty Flaminius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, nothing but an empty box Sir, which in my Lords behalfe, I come to intreat your Honor to ſup-ply: who hauing great and instant occasion to vse fiftie Talents, hath ſent to your Lordship to furnish him: no-thing doubting your present aſſistance therein.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: La, la, la, la: Nothing doubting ſayes hee? Alas good Lord, a Noble Gentleman ‘tis, if he would not keep ſo good a house. Many a time and often I ha din’d with him, and told him on't, and come againe to ſupper to him of purpose, to haue him ſpend leſſe, and yet he wold em-brace no counsell, take no warning by my comming, eue-ry man has his fault, and honesty is his. I ha told him on't, but I could nere get him from't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Please your Lordship, heere is the Wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Flaminius, I haue noted thee alwayes wise.
Heere's to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lordship ſpeakes your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue obserued thee alwayes for a towardlie prompt ſpirit, giue thee thy due, and one that knowes what belongs to reason; and canst vse the time wel, if the time vse thee well. Good parts in thee; get you gone ſir-rah. Draw neerer honeſt Flaminius. Thy Lords a boun-tifull Gentleman, but thou art wise, and thou know'st well enough (although thou com'st to me) that this is no time to lend money, especially vpon bare friendshippe without ſecuritie. Here's three Solidares for thee, good Boy winke at me, and ſay thou ſaw'st mee not. Fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible the world ſhould ſo much differ,
And we aliue that liued? Fly damned baseneſſe
To him that worships thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Now I ſee thou art a Foole, and fit for thy
Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: May these adde to the number y may ſcald thee:
Let moulten Coine be thy damnation,
Thou disease of a friend, and not himselfe:
Has friendship ſuch a faint and milkie heart,
It turnes in leſſe then two nights? O you Gods!
I feele my Masters paſſion. This Slaue vnto his Honor,
Has my Lords meate in him:
Why ſhould it thriue, and turne to Nutriment,
When he is turn’d to poyson?
O may Diseases onely worke vpon't:
And when he's ſicke to death, let not that part of Nature
Which my Lord payd for, be of any power
To expell ſickneſſe, but prolong his hower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Who the Lord Timon? He is my very good friend and an Honourable Gentleman.

We know him for no leſſe, thogh we are but ſtran-gers to him. But I can tell you one thing my Lord, and which I heare from common rumours, now Lord Timons happie howres are done and past, and his estate ſhrinkes from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucius.
SPEECH.LINE: Fye no, doe not beleeue it: hee cannot want for money.

But beleeue you this my Lord, that not long agœ, one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus, to borrow ſo many Talents, nay vrg’d extreamly for't, and ſhewed what neceſſity belong’d too't, and yet was deny’de.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: How?
I tell you, deny’de my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: What a ſtrange case was that? Now before the Gods I am asham’d on't. Denied that honourable man? There was verie little Honour ſhew’d in't. For my owne part, I must needes confeſſe, I haue receyued ſome ſmall kindneſſes from him, as Money, Plate, Iewels, and ſuch like Trifles; nothing comparing to his: yet had hee mi-stooke him, and ſent to me, I ſhould ne're haue denied his Occasion ſo many Talents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: See, by good hap yonders my Lord, I haue ſwet to ſee his Honor. My Honor’d Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruilius? You are kindely met ſir. Farthewell, commend me to thy Honourable vertuous Lord, my ve-ry exquisite Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: May it please your Honour, my Lord hath ſent—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? what ha's he ſent? I am ſo much endeered to that Lord; hee's euer ſending: how ſhall I thank him think'st thou? And what has he ſent now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: Has onely ſent his present Occasion now my Lord: requesting your Lordship to ſupply his instant vse with ſo many Talents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: I know his Lordship is but merry with me,
He cannot want fifty fiue hundred Talents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: But in the mean time he wants leſſe my Lord.
If his occasion were not vertuous,
I ſhould not vrge it halfe ſo faithfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou ſpeake ſeriously Seruilius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my ſoule ‘tis true Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: What a wicked Beast was I to disfurnish my ſelf against ſuch a good time, when I might ha ſhewn my ſelfe Honourable? How vnluckily it hapned, that I ſhold Purchase the day before for a little part, and vndo a great deale of Honour? Seruilius, now before the Gods I am not able to do (the more beast I ſay) I was ſending to vse Lord Timon my ſelfe, these Gentlemen can witneſſe; but I would not for the wealth of Athens I had done't now. Commend me bountifully to his good Lordship, and I hope his Honor will conceiue the fairest of mee, because I haue no power to be kinde. And tell him this from me, I count it one of my greatest afflictions ſay, that I cannot pleasure ſuch an Honourable Gentleman. Good Seruili-us, will you befriend mee ſo farre, as to vse mine owne words to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser
SPEECH.LINE: Yes ſir, I ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile looke you out a good turne Seruilius.
True as you ſaid, Timon is ſhrunke indeede,
And he that’s once deny’de, will hardly ſpeede.
Do you obserue this Hostilius?
I, to well.
Why this is the worlds ſoule,
And iust of the ſame peece
Is euery Flatterers ſport: who can call him his Friend
That dips in the ſame dish? For in my knowing
Timon has bin this Lords Father,
And kept his credit with his purse:
Supported his estate, nay Timons money
Has paid his men their wages. He ne're drinkes,
But Timons Siluer treads vpon his Lip,
And yet, oh ſee the monstrousneſſe of man,
When he lookes out in an vngratefull ſhape;
He does deny him (in respect of his)
What charitable men affoord to Beggers.
Religion grones at it.

For mine owne part, I neuer tasted Timon in my life Nor came any of his bounties ouer me, To marke me for his Friend. Yet I protest, For his right Noble minde, illustrious Vertue, And Honourable Carriage, Had his neceſſity made vse of me, I would haue put my wealth into Donation, And the best halfe ſhould haue return’d to him, So much I loue his heart: But I perceiue, Men must learne now with pitty to dispence, For Policy ſits aboue Conscience. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a third ſeruant with Sempronius, another of Timons Friends

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Semp.
SPEECH.LINE: Must he needs trouble me in't? Hum.
'Boue all others?
He might haue tried Lord Lucius, or Lucullus,
And now Ventidgius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeem’d from prison. All these
Owes their estates vnto him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord,
They haue all bin touch’d, and found Base-Mettle,
For they haue all denied him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Semp.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Haue they deny’de him?
Has Ventidgius and Lucullus deny’de him,
And does he ſend to me? Three? Humh?
It ſhewes but little loue, or iudgement in him.
Must I be his last Refuge? His Friends (like Physitians)
Thriue, giue him ouer: Must I take th’ Cure vpon me?
Has much disgrac’d me in't, I'me angry at him,
That might haue knowne my place. I ſee no ſense for't,
But his Occasions might haue woœd me first:
For in my conscience, I was the first man
That ere receiued guift from him.
And does he thinke ſo backwardly of me now,
That Ile requite it last? No:
So it may proue an Argument of Laughter
To th’ rest, and 'mong'st Lords be thought a Foole:
I’de rather then the worth of thrice the ſumme,
Had ſent to me first, but for my mindes ſake:
I’de ſuch a courage to do him good. But now returne,
And with their faint reply, this anſwer ioyne;
Who bates mine Honor, ſhall not know my Coyne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent: Your Lordships a goodly Villain: the diuell knew not what he did, when hee made man Poli-ticke; he croſſed himselfe by't: and I cannot thinke, but in the end, the Villanies of man will ſet him cleere. How fairely this Lord ſtriues to appeare foule? Takes Vertu-ous Copies to be wicked: like those, that vnder hotte ar-dent zeale, would ſet whole Realmes on fire, of ſuch a na-ture is his politike loue. This was my Lords best hope, now all are fled Saue onely the Gods. Now his Friends are dead, Doores that were ne're acquainted with their Wards Many a bounteous yeere, must be imploy’d Now to guard ſure their Master: And this is all a liberall course allowes, Who cannot keepe his wealth, must keep his house. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Varro's man, meeting others. All Timons Creditors to wait for his comming out. Then enter Lucius and Hortensius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.man.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met, goodmorrow Titus & Hortensius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: The like to you kinde Varro.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucius, what do we meet together?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and I think one busineſſe do's command vs all.
For mine is money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: So is theirs, and ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſir Philotus too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day at once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome good Brother.
What do you thinke the houre?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: Labouring for Nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: So much?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not my Lord ſeene yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Not yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder on't, he was wont to ſhine at ſeauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but the dayes are waxt ſhorter with him: You must consider, that a Prodigall course Is like the Sunnes, but not like his recouerable, I feare: ‘Tis deepest Winter in Lord Timons purse, that is: One may reach deepe enough, and yet finde little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: I am of your feare, for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſhew you how t’ obserue a ſtrange euent:
Your Lord ſends now for Money?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t true, he doe's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: And he weares Iewels now of Timons guift,
For which I waite for money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: It is against my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke how ſtrange it ſhowes,
Timon in this, ſhould pay more then he owes:
And e'ne as if your Lord ſhould weare rich Iewels,
And ſend for money for 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: I'me weary of this Charge,
The Gods can witneſſe:
I know my Lord hath ſpent of Timons wealth,
And now Ingratitude, makes it worse then ſtealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, mine's three thousand Crownes:
What's yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue thousand mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis much deepe, and it ſhould ſeem by th’ ſum
Your Masters confidence was aboue mine,
Else ſurely his had equall’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: One of Lord Timons men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Flaminius? Sir, a word: Pray is my Lord readie to come forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: No, indeed he is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: We attend his Lordship: pray ſignifie ſo much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Flam.
SPEECH.LINE: I need not tell him that, he knowes you are too diligent.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Steward in a Cloake, muffled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha: is not that his Steward muffled ſo?
He goes away in a Clowd: Call him, call him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare, ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: By your leaue, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: What do ye aske of me, my Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: We waite for certaine Money heere, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if Money were as certaine as your waiting,
'Twere ſure enough.
Why then preferr’d you not your ſummes and Billes
When your false Masters eate of my Lords meat?
Then they could ſmile, and fawne vpon his debts.
And take downe th’ Intrest into their glutt'nous Mawes.
You do your ſelues but wrong, to ſtirre me vp,
Let me paſſe quietly:
Beleeue't, my Lord and I haue made an end,
I haue no more to reckon, he to ſpend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but this anſwer will not ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: If't 'twill not ſerue, ‘tis not ſo base as you,
For you ſerue Knaues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: How? What does his casheer’d Worship mutter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Varro.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter what, hee's poore, and that’s re-uenge enough. Who can ſpeake broader, then hee that has no house to put his head in? Such may rayle against great buildings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heere's Seruilius: now wee ſhall know ſome answere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: If I might beseech you Gentlemen, to repayre ſome other houre, I ſhould deriue much from't. For tak't of my ſoule, my Lord leanes wondrously to discontent: His comfortable temper has forsooke him, he's much out of health, and keepes his Chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Many do keepe their Chambers, are not ſicke:
And if it be ſo farre beyond his health,
Me thinkes he ſhould the ſooner pay his debts,
And make a cleere way to the Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seruil.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titus.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot take this for anſwer, ſir.
Flaminius within.
Seruilius helpe, my Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are my dores oppos’d against my paſſage?
Haue I bin euer free, and must my house
Be my retentiue Enemy? My Gaole?
The place which I haue Feasted, does it now
(Like all Mankinde) ſhew me an Iron heart?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Put in now Titus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, heere is my Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Var.
SPEECH.LINE: And mine, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Var.
SPEECH.LINE: And ours, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Philo.
SPEECH.LINE: All our Billes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Knocke me downe with 'em, cleaue mee to the
Girdle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Cut my heart in ſummes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine, fifty Talents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell out my blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue thousand Crownes, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue thousand drops payes that.
What yours? and yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Var.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Var.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Teare me, take me, and the Gods fall vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I perceiue our Masters may throwe their caps at their money, these debts may well be call’d despe-rate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Timon.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue e'ene put my breath from mee the ſlaues. Creditors? Diuels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: My deere Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: What if it ſhould be ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue it ſo. My Steward?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: So fitly? Go, bid all my Friends againe,
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius Vllorxa: All,
Ile once more feast the Rascals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Lord, you onely ſpeake from your distra-cted ſoule; there's not ſo much left to furnish out a mo-derate Table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Be it not in thy care: Go I charge thee, inuite them all, let in the tide Of Knaues once more: my Cooke and Ile prouide.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter three Senators at one doore, Alcibiades meeting them, with Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, you haue my voyce, too't,
The faults Bloody:
‘Tis neceſſary he ſhould dye:
Nothing imboldens ſinne ſo much, as Mercy.
Mo’t true; the Law ſhall bruise 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Honor, health, and compaſſion to the Senate.
Now Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: I am an humble Sutor to your Vertues;
For pitty is the vertue of the Law,
And none but Tyrants vse it cruelly.
It pleases time and Fortune to lye heauie
Vpon a Friend of mine, who in hot blood
Hath ſtept into the Law: which is past depth
To those that (without heede) do plundge intoo't.
He is a Man (setting his Fate aside) of comely Vertues,
Nor did he ſoyle the fact with Cowardice.
(And Honour in him, which buyes out his fault)
But with a Noble Fury, and faire ſpirit,
Seeing his Reputation touch’d to death,
He did oppose his Fœ:
And with ſuch ſober and vnnoted paſſion
He did behooue his anger ere 'twas ſpent,
As if he had but prou’d an Argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: You vndergo too ſtrict a Paradox,
Striuing to make an vgly deed looke faire:
Your words haue tooke ſuch paines, as if they labour’d
To bring Man-slaughter into forme, and ſet Quarrelling
Vpon the head of Valour; which indeede
Is Valour mis-begot, and came into the world,
When Sects, and Factions were newly borne.
Hee's truly Valiant, that can wisely ſuffer
The worst that man can breath,
And make his Wrongs, his Out-sides,
To weare them like his Rayment, careleſſely,
And ne're preferre his iniuries to his heart,
To bring it into danger.
If Wrongs be euilles, and inforce vs kill,
What Folly ‘tis, to hazard life for Ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alci.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: You cannot make groſſe ſinnes looke cleare,
To reuenge is no Valour, but to beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alci.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lords, then vnder fauour, pardon me,
If I ſpeake like a Captaine.
Why do fond men expose themselues to Battell,
And not endure all threats? Sleepe vpon't,
And let the Fœs quietly cut their Throats
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such Valour in the bearing, what make wee
Abroad? Why then, Women are more valiant
That ſtay at home, if Bearing carry it:
And the Aſſe, more Captaine then the Lyon?
The fellow loaden with Irons, wiser then the Iudge?
If Wisedome be in ſuffering. Oh my Lords,
As you are great, be pittifully Good,
Who cannot condemne rashneſſe in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is ſinnes extreamest Gust,
But in defence, by Mercy, ‘tis mo’t iust.
To be in Anger, is impietie:
But who is Man, that is not Angrie.
Weigh but the Crime with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: You breath in vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alci.
SPEECH.LINE: In vaine?
His ſeruice done at Lacedemon, and Bizantium,
Were a ſufficient briber for his life.
What's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſay my Lords ha's done faire ſeruice,
And ſlaine in fight many of your enemies:
How full of valour did he beare himselfe
In the last Conflict, and made plenteous wounds?
He has made too much plenty with him:
He's a ſworne Riotor, he has a ſinne
That often drownes him, and takes his valour prisoner.
If there were no Fœs, that were enough
To ouercome him. In that Beastly furie,
He has bin knowne to commit outrages,
And cherrish Factions. ‘Tis inferr’d to vs,
His dayes are foule, and his drinke dangerous.
He dyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alci.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard fate: he might haue dyed in warre.
My Lords, if not for any parts in him,
Though his right arme might purchase his owne time,
And be in debt to none: yet more to moue you,
Take my deserts to his, and ioyne 'em both.
And for I know, your reuerend Ages loue Security,
Ile pawne my Victories, all my Honour to you
Vpon his good returnes.
If by this Crime, he owes the Law his life,
Why let the Warre receiue't in valiant gore,
For Law is ſtrict, and Warre is nothing more.
We are for Law, he dyes, vrge it no more
On height of our displeasure: Friend, or Brother,
He forfeits his owne blood, that ſpilles another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Must it be ſo? It must not bee:
My Lords, I do beseech you know mee.
How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Call me to your remembrances.
What.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot thinke but your Age has forgot me,
It could not else be, I ſhould proue ſo bace,
To ſue and be deny’de ſuch common Grace.
My wounds ake at you.
Do you dare our anger?
‘Tis in few words, but ſpacious in effect:
We banish thee for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Banish me?
Banish your dotage, banish vsurie,
That makes the Senate vgly.
If after two dayes ſhine, Athens containe thee,
Attend our waightier Iudgement.
And not to ſwell our Spirit,
He ſhall be executed presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Gods keepe you old enough,
That you may liue
Onely in bone, that none may looke on you.
I'm worse then mad: I haue kept backe their Fœs
While they haue told their Money, and let out
Their Coine vpon large interest. I my ſelfe,
Rich onely in large hurts. All those, for this?
Is this the Balsome, that the vsuring Senat
Powres into Captaines wounds? Banishment.
It comes not ill: I hate not to be banisht,
It is a cause worthy my Spleene and Furie,
That I may ſtrike at Athens. Ile cheere vp
My discontented Troopes, and lay for hearts;
‘Tis Honour with mo’t Lands to be at ods,
Souldiers ſhould brooke as little wrongs as Gods.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter diuers Friends at ſeuerall doores.

SPEECH.LINE: The good time of day to you, ſir.
I also wish it to you: I thinke this Honorable Lord did but try vs this other day.
Vpon that were my thoughts tyring when wee en-countred. I hope it is not ſo low with him as he made it ſeeme in the triall of his ſeuerall Friends.
It ſhould not be, by the perswasion of his new Fea-sting.
I ſhould thinke ſo. He hath ſent mee an earnest in-uiting, which many my neere occasions did vrge mee to put off: but he hath coniur’d mee beyond them, and I must needs appeare.
In like manner was I in debt to my importunat bu-sineſſe, but he would not heare my excuse. I am ſorrie, when he ſent to borrow of mee, that my Prouision was out.
I am ſicke of that greefe too, as I vnderstand how all things go.
Euery man heares ſo: what would hee haue borro-wed of you?
A thousand Peeces.
A thousand Peeces?
What of you?
He ſent to me ſir— Heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart Gentlemen both; and how fare you?
Euer at the best, hearing well of your Lordship.
The Swallow followes not Summer more willing, then we your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor more willingly leaues Winter, ſuch Sum-mer Birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not re-compence this long ſtay: Feast your eares with the Mu-sicke awhile: If they will fare ſo harshly o'th’ Trumpets ſound: we ſhall too't presently.
I hope it remaines not vnkindely with your Lord-ship, that I return’d you an empty Meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſir, let it not trouble you.
My Noble Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah my good Friend, what cheere?
My mo’t Honorable Lord, I am e'ne ſick of ſhame, that when your Lordship this other day ſent to me, I was ſo vnfortunate a Beggar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke not on't, ſir.
If you had ſent but two houres before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
Come bring in all together.
All couer’d Dishes.
Royall Cheare, I warrant you.
Doubt not that, if money and the ſeason can yeild it
How do you? What's the newes?
Alcibiades is banish’d: heare you of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Alcibiades banish’d?
‘Tis ſo, be ſure of it.
How? How?
I pray you vpon what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: My worthy Friends, will you draw neere?
Ile tell you more anon. Here's a Noble feast toward
This is the old man ſtill.
Wilt hold? Wilt hold?
It do's: but time will, and ſo.
I do conceyue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Each man to his ſtoole, with that ſpurre as hee would to the lip of his Mistris: your dyet ſhall bee in all places alike. Make not a Citie Feast of it, to let the meat coole, ere we can agree vpon the first place. Sit, ſit. The Gods require our Thankes. You great Benefactors, ſprinkle our Society with Thanke-fulneſſe. For your owne guifts, make your ſelues prais’d: But reserue ſtill to giue, least your Deities be despised. Lend to each man enough, that one neede not lend to another. For were your Godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the Gods. Make the Meate be beloued, more then the Man that giues it. Let no Aſſembly of Twenty, be without a ſcore of Villaines. If there ſit twelue Women at the Table, let a dozen of them bee as they are. The rest of your Fees, O Gods, the Senators of Athens, together with the common legge of People, what is amiſſe in them, you Gods, make ſuteable for destruction. For these my present Friends, as they are to mee nothing, ſo in nothing bleſſe them, and to nothing are they welcome. Vncouer Dogges, and lap. Some ſpeake. What do's his Lordship meane? Some other. I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Timon.
SPEECH.LINE: May you a better Feast neuer behold
You knot of Mouth-Friends: Smoke, & lukewarm water
Is your perfection. This is Timons last,
Who ſtucke and ſpangled you with Flatteries,
Washes it off and ſprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villany. Liue loath’d, and long
Mo’t ſmiling, ſmooth, detested Parasites,
Curteous Destroyers, affable Wolues, meeke Beares:
You Fooles of Fortune, Trencher-friends, Times Flyes,
Cap and knee-Slaues, vapours, and Minute Iackes.
Of Man and Beast, the infinite Maladie
Crust you quite o’re. What do'st thou go?
Soft, take thy Physicke first; thou too, and thou:
Stay I will lend thee money, borrow none.
What? All in Motion? Henceforth be no Feast,
Whereat a Villaine's not a welcome Guest.
Burne house, ſinke Athens, henceforth hated be
Of Timon Man, and all Humanity.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Senators, with other Lords.

SPEECH.LINE: How now, my Lords?
Know you the quality of Lord Timons fury?
Push, did you ſee my Cap?
I haue lost my Gowne.
He's but a mad Lord, & nought but humors ſwaies him. He gaue me a Iewell th’ other day, and now hee has beate it out of my hat. Did you ſee my Iewell?
Did you ſee my Cap.
Heere ‘tis.
Heere lyes my Gowne.
Let's make no ſtay.
Lord Timons mad.
I feel't vpon my bones.
One day he giues vs Diamonds, next day ſtones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me looke backe vpon thee. O thou Wall
That girdles in those Wolues, diue in the earth,
And fence not Athens. Matrons, turne incontinent,
Obedience fayle in Children: Slaues and Fooles
Plucke the graue wrinkled Senate from the Bench,
And minister in their ſteeds, to generall Filthes.
Conuert o'th’ Instant greene Virginity,
Doo't in your Parents eyes. Bankrupts, hold fast
Rather then render backe; out with your Kniues,
And cut your Trusters throates. Bound Seruants, ſteale,
Large-handed Robbers your graue Masters are,
And pill by Law. Maide, to thy Masters bed,
Thy Mistris is o'th’ Brothell. Some of ſixteen,
Plucke the lyn’d Crutch from thy old limping Sire,
With it, beate out his Braines. Piety, and Feare,
Religion to the Gods, Peace, Iustice, Truth,
Domesticke awe, Night-rest, and Neighbour-hood,
Instruction, Manners, Mysteries, and Trades,
Degrees, Obseruances, Customes, and Lawes,
Decline to your confounding contraries.
And yet Confusion liue: Plagues incident to men,
Your potent and infectious Feauors, heape
On Athens ripe for ſtroke. Thou cold Sciatica,
Cripple our Senators, that their limbes may halt
As lamely as their Manners. Lust, and Libertie
Creepe in the Mindes and Marrowes of our youth,
That 'gainst the ſtreame of Vertue they may ſtriue,
And drowne themselues in Riot. Itches, Blaines,
So we all th’ Athenian bosomes, and their crop
Be generall Leprosie: Breath, infect breath,
That their Society (as their Friendship) may
Be meerely poyson. Nothing Ile beare from thee
But nakedneſſe, thou detestable Towne,
Take thou that too, with multiplying Bannes:
Timon will to the Woods, where he ſhall finde
Th’ vnkindest Beast, more kinder then Mankinde.
The Gods confound (heare me you good Gods all)
Th’ Athenians both within and out that Wall:
And graunt as Timon growes, his hate may grow
To the whole race of Mankinde, high and low.
Amen.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Steward with two or three Seruants.

SPEECH.LINE: Heare you M[aster]. Steward, where's our Master?
Are we vndone, cast off, nothing remaining?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Alack my Fellowes, what ſhould I ſay to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous Gods,
I am as poore as you.
Such a House broke?
So Noble a Master falne, all gone, and not
One Friend to take his Fortune by the arme,
And go along with him.
As we do turne our backes
From our Companion, throwne into his graue,
So his Familiars to his buried Fortunes
Slinke all away, leaue their false vowes with him
Like empty purses pickt; and his poore ſelfe
A dedicated Beggar to the Ayre,
With his disease, of all ſhunn’d pouerty,
Walkes like contempt alone. More of our Fellowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: All broken Implements of a ruin’d house.
Yet do our hearts weare Timons Liuery,
That ſee I by our Faces: we are Fellowes ſtill,
Seruing alike in ſorrow: Leak’d is our Barke,
And we poore Mates, ſtand on the dying Decke,
Hearing the Surges threat: we must all part
Into this Sea of Ayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Fellowes all,
The latest of my wealth Ile ſhare among'st you.
Where euer we ſhall meete, for Timons ſake,
Let's yet be Fellowes. Let's ſhake our heads, and ſay
As 'twere a Knell vnto our Masters Fortunes,
We haue ſeene better dayes. Let each take ſome:
Nay put out all your hands: Not one word more,
Thus part we rich in ſorrow, parting poore.
Oh the fierce wretchedneſſe that Glory brings vs!
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
Since Riches point to Misery and Contempt?
Who would be ſo mock’d with Glory, or to liue
But in a Dreame of Friendship,
To haue his pompe, and all what ſtate compounds,
But onely painted like his varnisht Friends:
Poore honeſt Lord, brought lowe by his owne heart,
Vndone by Goodneſſe: Strange vnvsuall blood,
When mans worst ſinne is, He do's too much Good.
Who then dares to be halfe ſo kinde agen?
For Bounty that makes Gods, do ſtill marre Men.
My deerest Lord, blest to be mo’t accurst,
Rich onely to be wretched; thy great Fortunes
Are made thy cheefe Afflictions. Alas (kinde Lord)
Hee's flung in Rage from this ingratefull Seate
Of monstrous Friends:
Nor ha's he with him to ſupply his life,
Or that which can command it:
Ile follow and enquire him out.
Ile euer ſerue his minde, with my best will,
Whilst I haue Gold, Ile be his Steward ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: O bleſſed breeding Sun, draw from the earth Rotten humidity: below thy Sisters Orbe Infect the ayre. Twin’d Brothers of one wombe, Whose procreation, residence, and birth, Scarse is diuidant; touch them with ſeuerall fortunes, The greater ſcornes the leſſer. Not Nature (To whom all ſores lay ſiege) can beare great Fortune But by contempt of Nature. Raise me this Begger, and deny't that Lord, The Senators ſhall beare contempt Hereditary, The Begger Natiue Honor. It is the Pastour Lards, the Brothers ſides, The want that makes him leaue: who dares? who dares In puritie of Manhood ſtand vpright And ſay, this mans a Flatterer. If one be, So are they all: for euerie grize of Fortune Is ſmooth’d by that below. The Learned pate Duckes to the Golden Foole. All's obliquie: There's nothing leuell in our cursed Natures But direct villanie. Therefore be abhorr’d, All Feasts, Societies, and Throngs of men. His ſemblable, yea himselfe Timon disdaines, Destruction phang mankinde; Earth yeeld me Rootes, Who ſeekes for better of thee, ſawce his pallate With thy mo’t operant Poyson. What is heere? Gold? Yellow, glittering, precious Gold? No Gods, I am no idle Votarist, Roots you cleere Heauens. Thus much of this will make Blacke, white; fowle, faire; wrong, right; Base, Noble; Old, young; Coward, valiant. Ha you Gods! why this? what this, you Gods? why this Will lugge your Priests and Seruants from your ſides: Plucke ſtout mens pillowes from below their heads. This yellow Slaue, Will knit and breake Religions, bleſſe th’ accurst, Make the hoare Leprosie ador’d, place Theeues, And giue them Title, knee, and approbation With Senators on the Bench: This is it That makes the wappen’d Widdow wed againe; Shee, whom the Spittle-house, and vlcerous ſores, Would cast the gorge at. This Embalmes and Spices To'th’ Aprill day againe. Come damn’d Earth, Thou common whore of Mankinde, that puttes oddes Among the rout of Nations, I will make thee Do thy right Nature. March afarre off. Ha? A Drumme? Th'art quicke, But yet Ile bury thee: Thou't go (strong Theefe) When Gowty keepers of thee cannot ſtand: Nay ſtay thou out for earnest.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alcibiades with Drumme and Fife in warlike manner, and Phrynia and Timandra

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou there? ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: A Beast as thou art. The Canker gnaw thy hart
For ſhewing me againe the eyes of Man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: What is thy name? Is man ſo hatefull to thee,
That art thy ſelfe a Man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I am Misantropos, and hate Mankinde.
For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dogge,
That I might loue thee ſomething.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alc.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thee well:
But in thy Fortunes am vnlearn’d, and ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tim.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thee too, and more then that I know thee
I not desire to know. Follow thy Drumme,
With mans blood paint the ground Gules, Gules:
Religious Cannons, ciuill Lawes are cruell,
Then what ſhould warre be? This fell whore of thine,
Hath in her more destruction then thy Sword,
For all her Cherubin looke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phrin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy lips rot off.
